title: Wednesday, 9th October 2019
bodyHTML:
11:04 am
BE11:04am

Morning, then. Markets Live.

Soundbuy Morning
2s10s Hi
BE11:04am

The stocks, with their going up and down.

BE11:05am

And the cry of gulls, and the deep sea swell, and the profit and loss.

cheeckychappy @BE - sick as a parrot
11:05 am
BE11:05am

Few things to get through today.

2s10s Scotland 60 Russia 0
BE11:05am

Bookmakers, of course.

BE11:05am

And a bit of Micro Focus, maybe.

11:06 am
BE11:06am

And Brexit, probably, because always Brexit.

BE11:06am

First, though, there's this:

BE11:06am

Thoughts live from Extinction Rebellion protests

VV75 morning
MnM Go Fiji!
GBKrona Hola
VV75 I read somewhere they are getting 40k in daily donations
11:07 am
BE11:07am

Yep, really. Barclays' European E&P team went down to speak to the ExRebs to backtest their investment recommendations.

GBKrona have to admire Extinction Rebellion
BE11:07am

As the sense of urgency about mitigating the effect of greenhouse gasses has grown in recent months from social media, government and investors alike, so too has the polarisation of debate about what role the large cap energy companies play in a lower carbon world. In our report “Engaging Gen Z key to re-rating” (17 April 2019) we highlighted that being seen as part of the solution to climate change is key to the societal license to operate, and ultimately longer term share price performance.

BE11:08am

Given this we decided to use a somewhat grey and wet afternoon to go and meet some of the Extinction Rebellion protesters currently occupying central London.

Ulster Pension Fund Morning all
PBateman Morning everyone
11:09 am
BE11:09am

And .... they seem slightly surprised not to have been shouted at.

BE11:09am

There was a remarkable willingness to engage and the findings surprised us a little – including the call for a carbon tax and an acknowledgement that the solutions aren’t easy. However, it was also clear that the oil companies are not seen as doing enough to solve the issue of climate change with the scale of investment still too low.

BE11:10am

We should salute this kind of thing. It's good to listen to all opinions, particularly if you have a great big buffer of pension fund money separating you from reality.

11:11 am
BE11:11am

Conclusions wise:

BE11:11am

We acknowledge that the protestors may not be the target investor audience, but the concerns from institutional investors about the terminal value of oil companies in a two-degree environment are for us having a meaningful impact on share price performance. We remain convinced that environmental and technology strategies will be key determinants of competitiveness in the coming decade. In this context we highlight Equinor, where it is already clear its renewables business is adding value, and it is a leader in delivering low cost oil and gas.

BE11:11am

Also:

FATDAZ Can't see comments on the left today anyone else having issues ?
11:11 am
BE11:12am

When asked if they would ever buy shares in BP and Shell, there was surprisingly careful consideration and in a very non-scientific survey about 75% of the protestors said they would – but only if the majority of investments were renewables.

PBateman Meanwhile at the Daily Express, Pound SOARS on news of EU CAPITULATION
rw42 So they'd buy BP and shell if BP and shell weren't BP and shell any more?
graunch wotcha
BE11:13am

Which is a new avenue for the sales folks, I guess. Get yourself a yoga mat.

1st Lt. Fletcher Christian Good moaning.
chad_john Morning. Coleen Rooney to win this year's Pulitzer? (see Twitter)
undefined
#REF! re: note, this stuff is important.. for markering. ESG is a big theme in marketing funds to public and to pension funds. so having ESG insights are needed (as much for marketing as insights)
2s10s @chad_john: wags at war
11:13 am
BE11:13am

Apologies, ROTR, if there are technical troubles. Apologies also if there' not.

Patience @rw42 - didn't BP try to brand themselves as 'Beyond Petroleum'? They get the picture.
BE11:14am

And to RNS, where GVC's the biggest thing.

GVC Holdings PLC (GVC:LSE): Last: 773.80, up 23.8 (+3.17%), High: 783.60, Low: 760.60, Volume: 1.80m
11:14 am
BE11:14am

Profit ahead.

BE11:15am

Though it's debatable whether it's a useful beat, as it's UK over-the-counter wagering.

BE11:15am

UK Retail trends following the cut in maximum B2 stakes to £2 on 1 April 2019 remain ahead of expectations. Like-for-like OTC NGR was 7% ahead of last year driven by the part-substitution of displaced machines revenues. Like-for-like machines NGR was 36% behind, as a result of the B2 machines stakes cut. A further 41 shops were closed during the period, taking the total closed as a result of the Triennial Review to 198. The Group expects to close a total of up to 900 shops across the next two years.

Puntino GE are doing some interesting work with hybrid gas turbines.
11:16 am
BE11:16am

So .... Ladbrokes and William Hill close a load of shops and put limits on the amounts chronically addicted gamblers can feed into the roulette machines.

2s10s Thomas Cook: all 555 high street shops grabbed in one swoop by Hays Travel. Already 421 ex-TC staff have been hired by Hays
BE11:17am

So, like-for-like revenue on the nags and the dogs goes up.

BE11:17am

I wonder why shop closures result in a boost to LFL?

11:17 am
BE11:17am

BE11:17am

It's a real mystery, that.

BE11:17am

Irish HF guy Morning all, BE, any grey on Intu Properties 18% fall yesterday to £0.36 or is it just mean reversion! @2s10s, interesting, I must look at Thomas Cook news from the liquidator
11:18 am
BE11:18am

Turning to numbers .....

BE11:18am

Here's Goldman:

BE11:18am

GVC released its 3Q19 trading update this morning (9 October), raising the FY19 EBITDA pre-IFRS 16 guidance range to £670-680mn (from £650-670mn), now 2% ahead of GSe at the mid-point.
For the 3Q, NGR growth of -2% cFX was broadly in line with our expectations for 2H19 (-3%). Online sports revenue grew 15% yoy in cFX (+22% adjusted for the World Cup), with sportsbook stakes up 5% and win margins up 1pp yoy. Gaming NGR was up 7% cFX in 3Q (vs. GSe 2H19: 13%) owing to tougher comps related to high cross-sell into gaming during the World Cup. UK Retail trends post the FOBTs impact remain ahead of GVC’s initial guidance.

11:19 am
BE11:19am

Still no chairman at GVC, I note. I'd have thought there would be a queue of people wanting to take orders from Kenny.

BE11:20am

And Peel Hunt:

BE11:20am

GVC’s share price is down 17% over the past year but up by
12% over the past month. Today’s trading statement is likely to
maintain that momentum with a small upgrade driven by strong
trading and lower financing charges. The longer GVC continues
to execute well, the better its chance of escaping the dog house.

FATDAZ Still can't see what @BE is writing
1966AndAllThat I gather a key reason for betting shops being kept open is people top up their internet accounts with cash. (Source my cleaner who was just made redundant by William Hill). Sounds like lots of AML issues and getting around problem gambling "controls"
Delta1_ETF https://www.thetimes.co.uk/edition/news/boris-johnson-gets-last-chance-to-keep-brexit-deal-alive-9zm5qltvt
11:21 am
BE11:22am

Peel Hunt did that very good note a day or two ago about how GVC would be sensible to use Fluter's offer for Stars as a stalking-horse bid.

SoS No doubt they (betting shops) will all become nail bars.
BE11:23am

As in: hang around to see if the CMA and its Australian equivalent blocks the retail side of the deal.

BE11:23am

Then counterbid, or not, with a level of clarity currently unavailable to Flutter.

11:23 am
BE11:23am

The longer GVC trades well, and pays down debt, the more
plausible such a blockbuster deal becomes. And even if Stars is not the target, we believe that GVC will execute another major acquisition. Flutter/Stars shows that consolidation isn’t slowing down. Continued successful execution will reassure shareholders in GVC and providers of M&A finance alike.

undefined
BE11:24am

Speaking of Flutter .....

11:24 am
BE11:24am

Citigroup not keen.

BE11:25am

Trading rather than the merger, in concept, but the antitrust angle is a problem too.

BE11:25am

We have concerns on Flutter’s momentum in its core UK online and Australian divisions, regulatory risks of market switch-offs (£11m EBITDA hit in 2019e), and its valuation discrepancy vs. peers GVC and William Hill. The planned TSG merger would significantly narrow (but not close) Flutter’s valuation differential, further strengthen its US position, but increase its unregulated market exposure. Given these positives our TP increases to £74.50 from £51.00; Sell.

Shinshin No acknowledgement from Swampy that if they see CO2 as the major problem, then more nukes is the answer ?
2s10s UK Parliament to sit on Saturday 19th Oct, same day as People's Vote March.
11:27 am
BE11:27am

Okay, so Citi's main uncertainty is re cross selling.

BE11:28am

Because Stars has a lot of poker customers, and it's not obvious why they would also want to punt on sports.

BE11:29am

Against that, you have swapping cheap shares for expensive ones.

11:29 am
BE11:29am

A key advantage of the proposed merger for Flutter is the multiple arbitrage created from the valuation discrepancy between Flutter and TSG pre the announcement. We see 3.1x of EBITDA multiple and 6.9x of P/E multiple contraction on 2020e (close price on merger announcement day).

undefined
VV75 pokerplayers are gamblers by definition, even though they tout poker being skill based.
FATDAZ Re Co2 Emissions etc will be interesting to see what proportion of our energy generation renewables as the days grow shorter and sun is lower in the sky I guess the offset will be wind blowing a bit more in winter .......?
FATDAZ Renewables account for should say
den @shinshin - wonder where Swampy is now.
Soundbuy Scapa update - a tad flat this morning..........and no ConvaTec update
BE11:32am

(@VV75: possibly. But the history of online poker suggests a difficult, rather silo'd market that functions rather like a CFD broker in its ability to rinse newbies.)

luzh @vv75, I would say that while there is a baseline among poker players who are just gamblers, the boom of a decade ago (which has now mostly subsided) was mostly players who liked the game in itself
11:32 am
BE11:32am

Okay, what else? Intu? If we must.

Intu Properties PLC (INTU:LSE): Last: 35.76, down 0.36 (-1.00%), High: 37.76, Low: 35.31, Volume: 2.34m
Shinshin @den He popped up in the press this morning
den @shinshin - how do we know it was him?
chad_john (Rebekah Vardy has responded. Twitter has gone into meltdown).
BE11:33am

There was a pretty good sector note from Credit Suisse that we didn't mention yesterday

chad_john Ahem, sorry, Intu.
Irish HF guy @BE, yesterday the share price fell 18%, no news as far I can see..
Shinshin @den I guess he stood out with his unkempt appearance, raggedy hairstyle, and unrealistic goals.
11:35 am
BE11:35am

On the assumption that it was going elsewhere on the FT.com site ... which proved optimistic. So let's retread here.

den @shinshin - excellent !!
BE11:36am

Brexit bad. Uncertainty. Keep selling Intu, British Land, LandSecs.

BE11:36am

Our UK coverage trades at a discount to our Dec-19E NAV of 19%, which has narrowed from c.30% over the summer, yet clearly still indicates a lack of belief in valuation growth potential and/or concern over heightened risk. Whilst the range of potential Brexit outcomes remains wide, the most supportive outcome for UK property of a soft Brexit followed by political stability appears highly unlikely.

den @shinshin - wonder what he's been doing all these years.
11:36 am
BE11:37am

But buy Hammerson on that luxury brand outlet thing it only partly owns.

BE11:37am

Hammerson’s share price values its attractive Outlets portfolio (27% of group value) at c.40% below book value after applying peer multiples to the rest of the portfolio. Coupled with a 10% earnings yield and mid-7% implied property yield, we think the stock offers attractive value, both relative and absolute. CapCo’s share price implies Earl’s Court is worth c.80% below book value, which also appears mis-priced. Meanwhile, Segro remains the key beneficiary of disruption through booming demand for logistics space.

BE11:38am

Want the Brexit flowchart? Course you do.

11:37 am
BE11:38am

2s10s 2%+18% crash out from Credit Suisse, are you kidding me, its higher than 50% now.
BE11:38am

And on Intu it says:

BE11:39am

[W]e think Intu now has a lot of downside potential written into its share price, which is implying a c.30% fall in property values (on top of over 20% fall in the last 18 months), and which offers an implied property yield of over 7%, more than 3ppts higher than Segro's. However, a weak balance sheet (58% LTV at H1, above the Board’s 50% upper limit) has effectively made a forced seller of management in a market where investor interest is minimal as long-term rental growth is so difficult to estimate. In the meantime, management is preparing for the disposal of its best assets – a portfolio of Spanish centres (7% of GAV) and a stake in Intu Trafford (28% of GAV). A takeover remains a possibility given two recent attempts to sell the company, albeit this is unlikely to be before Brexit is resolved and potential buyers may prefer to wait until closer to refinancing events in 2021. Intu has the highest upside to our potential Blue Sky value, but we maintain our Underperform rating as property values are continuing to fall and the dividend remains suspended.

chomsky On betting shops - there's a limit of 4 machines per shop, hence why there are so many betting shops. More shops = more machines = more profit
11:40 am
BE11:40am

Note also the (accidentally released) terrible BRC figures earlier in the week, which noted specifically that online sales were fine but store sales had been terrible.

chomsky Reducing the stakes might look good on the surface but it pushes punters to online gambling where there are no limits and no shop members to keep an eye on your habit
Bulletin Board Bag Carrier they think a crashout is clearly very unlikely hmm
Forester Am I missing something or do all the odds on the Brexit flow chart not add up to 100%?
undefined
luzh @chomsky yes, but it's easier to implement controls and regulations online, because you can track users, allow them to see their P/L, etc. In theory.
BE11:43am

Are we doing Brexit again over there?

Pete @den this is what Swampy has been up to, if you believe wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swampy_(environmentalist)
chomsky @Luzh you'd think, but pushing it online is bad news. I'm not sure if you've seen all the fines william hill/ladbrokes have been hit with for allowing people with gambling addictions to use their platforms - £80k upwards per customer. It's not safe or controlled and to think the betting companies want more regulation is a fallacy
VV75 I rather hope not
11:44 am
BE11:44am

I guess we are. So ........ cable is now unchanged on the day post that Times story about Europe making concessions: https://www.thetim...al-alive-9zm5qltvt

tangledodyssey Nope, Brexit Flexit, immune to it now.
Sails @Forester you are correct, Credit Suisse have mislaid 15%
Forester Judging by the number of Texts, Emails, App Notifications I get every days from the (major) bookies they are still very keen to get more of my money!
Irish HF guy Guys, the General Election on the right is 15% which is an end point.
tangledodyssey Concessions means not actually annexing NI outright?
luzh @chomsky I definitely don't believe that they want more regulation, but online at least it's theoretically possible. In shops there is no accountability at all.
BE11:47am

(@Forester: the way to stop them emailing you is to leave £10 in your account. Weirdly, they grow a lot less keen on reminding you of their existence when they have your money.)

luzh The big red "Cons majority" box actually contains 30% if you read the text
den @Pete - Many thanks for that - he's almost establishment now !!
BE11:48am

Here's JPMorgan to talk us through the extension, which we are getting no matter what anyone says because it's the law and stuff.

11:48 am
BE11:48am

The Benn Act in the UK requires the PM to ask for an extension until the end of January, to agree to that immediately should the EU agree to that date, but to return to the Commons for further instruction within 48 hours if the EU proposes an extension of different length. On the EU side, the prospect of the UK remaining as a possibly obstructive member with a veto could prevent it from completing its legislative tasks. However, the main piece of business to be concluded in the coming months is the agreement of a new multi-year budget, an agreement which would be expected to be reached next summer at the earliest and possibly not until later in the year (the new agreement will take effect at the beginning of 2021). Hence the option of an extension until the end of the summer is open given that there is not obviously important business that the UK could block until then.

BE11:49am

Back when Article 50 was extended earlier this year, the EU initially granted a short two-week extension in an attempt to give PM May a final opportunity to pass the withdrawal agreement. It then agreed the 6 month extension to end October. It did so as the result of a compromise between two positions. Barnier, Macron and others wanted a short (3 month) extension in order to keep the pressure on the UK to come to a political decision and agree something close to the existing deal. Donald Tusk and most other members of the EU were minded to grant a longer extension (up to 12 months), at least partly in the hope that would give time for the UK to reconsider its decision and perhaps hold a second referendum, and reflecting a desire not to have the exhausting Brexit issue dominate the agenda at regular intervals. The 6 month extension agreed as a compromise is typically seen as ultimately having vindicated more of the Barnier-Macron position – that in the absence of pressure to take a decision, time will simply be wasted by the UK, and it is not clear that the UK position has “softened” on the back of being given more time. That knowledge lies in the background as the EU considers how to proceed now. It faces basically three choices of extension length: short, medium and long.

BE11:49am

So. Extension the short:

11:49 am
BE11:49am

The EU could seek to force the current UK Parliament to make a choice between a limited set of options by allowing only 2-3 weeks of extension and threatening no further extension beyond that date. For example, it could state that the UK can choose between two versions of the backstop to be included in the Withdrawal Agreement: a full border in the Irish sea solution (with Northern Ireland alone remaining aligned with a subset of single market and customs union rules) or the hybrid version negotiated by PM May (Northern Ireland aligns with single market subset, all of UK aligns with customs union). The EU would engage in a short period (say one week) of intense negotiations to clarify the options, and then convene an emergency Council summit in late November where it would expect the UK to indicate its choice of backstop or no-deal. In the event of a deal, a short technical extension would be allowed for ratification of the Treaty, and the UK’s EU exit could then occur on January 1st. The EU would be offering the opportunity to “Get Brexit Done” to a Parliament more inclined to agree to its terms than go ahead with no-deal.

Waterloo Whoops. Split the difference between $10bn and 10m tones.
BE11:50am

Extension the medium, taking us through January:

Bulletin Board Bag Carrier what happens if the UK doesn't request an extension, yet uk law says a no deal is not possible?
BE11:50am

An extension of this length allows enough time for the general election most (ourselves included) expect will ensue if time is available after Article 50 is extended. The exact timing and outturn of such an election is unpredictable, but an extension to January would leave at most a couple of months before the post-election administration faced an Article 50 deadline; should an election be delayed until January, it could leave only a matter of a couple of weeks. Extending beyond end January to a different date in Q1/early Q2 would make it more likely (though still far from guaranteed) that there would be more time to negotiate with the post-election administration.

Shinshin "The three options are short, medium, or long". Incisive stuff there.
2s10s Other EU 27 may argue over the term of the extension and then in the bad temper refuse to agree to one at all.
11:50 am
BE11:50am

And extension the long:

BE11:51am

An extension of this length plausibly allows time for both a general
election and a second referendum to occur, and would widely be perceived as an invitation from the EU for the UK to once again reconsider the exit decision. That length of extension also plausibly opens up a wider range of political possibilities as we move toward the end of that extension, including changes in the leadership of UK political parties and consequent changes in their approach to Brexit. Of course, the possibility that the UK will find itself similarly unable to muster a political majority to take and implement a well-defined decision on Brexit at that point will remain.

tangledodyssey So the Westminster Nightmare continues
BE11:52am

They all have their attractions, says JPM. But only the short extension will keep Boris's balls in a vice.

11:51 am
BE11:52am

(I apologise for that image.)

Bulletin Board Bag Carrier hahah
BE11:52am

[I]f we had the ear of the EU council at this stage our advice to them would be simple given our understanding of their objectives. Keep an extension very short, and force the existing House of Commons to make a decision on how to proceed on the basis of a deal very close to that already configured. In our view, the risk of a UK general election returning a majority prepared to implement no-deal, and with a set of demands for a deal the EU simply will not meet, is uncomfortably high. There is a risk that the existing House of Commons would opt for no-deal if forced to choose between two variants of the existing Withdrawal Agreement, but we do not see that as large. A larger risk is that the EU’s Article 50 deadline would not be viewed as hard constraint, and UK politicians would seek to avoid making a choice and to create further time for negotiation on a deal. However, the extent to which the EU makes the terms of an extension clear are largely within its own hands. If it wants to create the expectation of a “hard” deadline, in our view, it can.

BE11:53am

So what will happen in practice? At this point, our bias is to think that the EU will agree to something close to the UK’s request of a 3 month extension or perhaps a little longer, once again reflecting a compromise between disparate views on the Council. It will be important to see in the coming days whether the arguments made in the past by Barnier and Macron, that a short extension must be used to force UK decision making, emerge with more force and get more support on the Council.

11:53 am
BE11:53am

That's Malcolm Barr at JPM.

Shinshin Story unchanged since Johnson took over though - eternal circle until election, election depends on how much of a deal is cut with Farage, Farage on board = no deal exit; not on board = hung parliament, rinse and repeat.
SoS I want a medium-rare extension please
undefined
Shinshin Maybe put Coleen in charge of negotiations ? She seems to be able to work stuff out.
tangledodyssey Three and a half years already. Gawd!
Bulletin Board Bag Carrier unless borris has a way to pass the no deal uk law?
BE11:56am

Apologies if that seemed distracted, I was trying to work out who Coleen Rooney and Rebekah Vardy were and whether we needed to care.

11:56 am
BE11:56am

Seems not! Right, back to stocks.

VV75 we don't
Micro Focus International PLC (MCRO:LSE): Last: 1,058, up 4.4 (+0.42%), High: 1,076, Low: 1,040, Volume: 370.02k
2s10s Boris could resign Oct 19th, less HM opp flail around then election.
BE11:57am

Had a mention a day or so ago on the fact that it was making new 52w lows

11:57 am
BE11:57am

Which was largely on Numis pulling back 2020/21 forecasts

2s10s @BE: WAGS Live
BE11:58am

Against that, of course, you have a company openly inviting offers

BE12:00pm

Which tends to spark rumours both about piecemeal disposals and bigger stuff. The strategic review isn't due until early next year but I'm getting the impression from punters that they'd quite like to hear something rather earlier.

12:00 pm
BE12:00pm

Anyway, I mention because Paul Morland at Panmure is pushing.

tangledodyssey Hays Travel taking on 555 Thomas Cook shops. Optimism reigns, no idea why. Landlords capitulating on rents, I suppose.
BE12:01pm

You remember Paul Morland, right? He became embroiled in the Autonomy trial for advising clients to sell Autonomy.

BE12:01pm

We believe the Micro Focus share price reflects a pessimism that ignores a track record that includes 43% compound TSRs for five years up until April 2017 and the $2.5bn sale of SUSE for a profit of $1.7bn. Management face some significant headwinds related to the HPE deal but the shares appear to discount zero chance of progress. We do not share this view and we initiate with a Buy rating and 1530p target price.

2s10s #ThomasCook: when they say Hays has bought the shops, are they talking about buying out the commercial lease (typically 7 years, isn't it?) ?
Soundbuy Adept technology off nigh on 10% - anybody cover/care?
12:02 pm
BE12:02pm

Two profit warnings in fifteen months since the HPE Software deal appear to have eliminated all confidence in a management team that has proven to be a reliable generator of shareholder returns over the long term. A business model that prioritises shareholder returns over growth has been pilloried by the bears after the $8.8bn acquisition of HPE Software in late 2017 failed to deliver on its promises. Our analysis suggests that while mistakes have been made, the model is not broken and we believe the outcome of the strategic review will represent the first step on the road to rebuilding a long-term reputation for maximising shareholder returns through the execution of an unconventional, but highly effective business model, focused on margins and cash.

tangledodyssey No idea but reportedly all the TC high street shops are to reopen immediately.
BE12:03pm

Price suggests a worst-case scenario of accelerating revenue declines and stagnating margins, which looks unlikely given management's trying to clean out the crap, he says.

BE12:04pm

The market appears to be fixated with the top line and is, in our view, underestimating management’s potential to slow revenue declines, take out more costs, raise margins, generate cash and re-establish its strong cash-generating credentials and delivery of high TSRs. Micro Focus may have missed its revenue guidance for two consecutive years, but it has also improved margins by 650 bps over the same period. The model is not broken in our view and we see earnings growth at a minimum of 6% per annum over the three forecast years. We base our target price on a 10x P/E multiple, a 25% discount to the market, and we carry out a sensitivity analysis concluding that even if revenues continue to decline at -6% per annum for the next six years (PG -5% for FY20E and improving thereafter), the business’s total free cash generation would be equivalent to today’s market capitalization. We believe the shares are materially undervalued and will respond positively to the outcome of the ongoing strategic review.

MnM Wales RWC effort 2nd half beckons, cheers all
12:04 pm
undefined
Brutto Quite a few US legacy tech businesses have made a virtue of managing declining revenues...
tangledodyssey BE, thank you and good afternoon.
BE12:06pm

Hey, look at the time.

GBKrona thanks @BE
2s10s bye
VV75 thank you
BE12:07pm

Thomas Cook news here if you want it: https://www.ft.com...-85f4-d00e5018f061

12:06 pm
BE12:07pm

Thomas Cook’s shop estate has been bought by independent travel agents Hays Travel in a deal that could see it re-employee many of the collapsed travel firms former employees.

Hays, which is the UK’s largest independent travel agent, has agreed to buy 555 of Thomas Cook’s 563 UK stores for an undisclosed sum. It has already recruited 421 of Thomas Cook’s employees and said that it had “further offers outstanding” to others.

Brutto Thanks!
BE12:07pm

Don't have the figure handy, but wasn't a very large proportion of Thomas Cook bookings done through the retail estate?

BE12:09pm

So much so that there was an argument that it could've gone Private Eye. Take the web presence back to nothing and turn itself into a place for the customers that come in every single year to look at the brochures and speak to a travel agent.

12:10 pm
BE12:10pm

And I imagine that's precisely the market Hays targets, so it makes sense on the surface. High Street monopoly for pensioners' beach holidays.

BE12:11pm

Right, anyway, that'll do.

BE12:11pm

Ta for the comments, which were appreciated whether or not you could see this side of the page.

Soundbuy Cheers...................
12:11 pm
BE12:11pm

Back tomorrow. Afternoon all.
